Walking Horses

Benefit Georgia

The Tennessee Walking Horse, originally developed for use as a plantation horse, has become one of the top pleasure and show horse breeds in America. The Georgia Walking Horse Exhibitors Association is a group of Georgians who either own or are interested in this beautiful breed.

The association is a non-profit group that was organized in 1955. It

I has grown from 21 (people to a memI bership pushing ]400 families, j More important than size is the spirited involvement shown by each member. This group has consisI tantly been active in promoting this fine animal within our state. Their efforts have been so successful that the Tennessee Walking Horse now enjoys the reputation of attracting the largest number of spectators of any breed in the state. In efforts to promote the breed, the G.W.H.E.A. presents a beautiful

(Our guest columnist this week is Jim

Gullett, Past President "and Show Chairman of the Georgia Walking Horse Exhibitors Association, P. 0. Box 96, Duluth 30136.)

trophy each year to the 4-H Club Walking Horse High Point winner and cooperates in other 4-H Club activities. To encourage members to show their horses within the state of Ga., the association offers permanant silver trophies at the end of the year in all catagories to horses who have earned the most points within the state.

The G.W.H.E.A. is the largest organized state walking horse association in the United States and is also known to be the most active. They are first to come out publicly for anything that is for the betterment of the breed.

Choose Inoculants

For Soybeans Carefully

Inoculation is necessary in soybean production. The proper selection of the right seed inoculant is important. Inoculants are different for various legumes; therefore, the specific inoculant for soybeans should be chosen ^ according to Ben Kittrel, Extension Agronomist, soybeans.

Growers should avoid using inoculants that are pre-mixed with either molybdenum or a fungicide or combination of the three. Recent tests at the University of Georgia have shown that where these pre-mixed materials were used, no nodules were formed on the roots of the soybean plant.

Growers desiring to use a fungicide and/or molybdenum along with an inoculant should purchase these materials separately and thoroughly mix them with the seed at the time of planting. There are several pre-mixed materials on the market and the grower should discuss this with his supplier to make sure he is getting the desired materials.

Where fields have not had soybeans planted during the last several years there is a definite need to supply the seed with enough viable bacteria to get good nodulation. Therefore, the selection and use of the right inoculant is very important to insure the best potential yields.

Horse Show Edition

Deadline March 26

The deadline for the April 7 Show edition is March 26. Show Listings for April, May and June will be included. The next horse show edition will not be published until July.

Pruning Shrubs Properly

Requires Correct Shears

Hedge shears are not the ideal type of pruning equipment to reduce the size of shrubs that have become slightly too large for their location. A much better job can be done by the use of hand pruners or lopping shears; according to Gerald Smith, Extension Horticulturist.

Note in the photograph that the 'Dwarf Burford' holly has become quite large. It was easy to reduce the height of this plant simply by pruning out the longest and tallest limbs down inside the plant. Notice in the "after" photograph how much of the plant has been removed without giving the shrub a pruned or unnatural appearance.

In doing this type of pruning it is important to make the cuts well .inside the body of the plant. If this is done strong, vigorous growth will not develop on the resulting stubs. If we cut off the lower limbs on the surface of the foliage mass of the shrub, the exposed stubs will produce very vigorous growth again in a matter of weeks.

Pruning to reduce shrub size can be done almost any time of year on a vast majority of shrubs without any detrimental effect.

Home EC Dean Poultry Federation

Receives Award

Dr. Emily Pou, dean of the school of home economics at the University of Georgia, has received the Friend of Extension Home Economics award.

The Georgia Association of Extension Home Economists selected Dr. Pou for her outstanding contributions to the Extension home economics program. The award was presented at the Association's annual meeting in Macon.

Holds Annual Meet

A quarter of a century of Georgia Poultry Federation service and the Bicentennial of the United States will be commemorated at th.e Annual Spring Meeting at Callaway Gardens, April 2-4. President Lee Arrendale urges all Federation members to attend the 25th Anniversary Meeting.

Mix salt and flour, cut in the shortening and add water

to form soft ball. Divide the pastry in half. Roll one half of

pastry out on pastry cloth, add 1/2 of marinated apples,

slice 1/2 stick of butter over apples, add 1 tbs. sour cream

and roll into a firm roll. Place the roll in a deep dish pie

pan and sprinkle sugar and cinnamon over top. Place in

the oven at 450 degrees for ten minutes, then pour 1/2

cup boiling water in pan and continue cooking until roll

turns to a golden brown. Roll out other half of pastry and

repeat above process.
